description: Uncertain; probably a collateral form of brusque, but compare Irish briosc, Scottish Gaelic brisg, Welsh brwysg.

adjectives.description: brisk (comparative brisker or more brisk, superlative briskest or most brisk)

entries.meaning: Full of liveliness and activity; characterized by quickness of motion or action.
examples: We took a brisk walk yesterday.

entries.meaning: Full of spirit of life; effervescing.

examples: This morning was a brisk fall day. It wasn't cold enough for frost, but you wanted to keep moving.

entries.meaning: Abrupt, curt in one's manner or in relation to others.

verbs.description: brisk (third-person singular simple present brisks, present participle brisking, simple past and past participle brisked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, intransitive, often with "up") To make or become lively; to enliven; to animate.
